reviewText: ...the psychiatrist frequently asks of Jesse Stone. He is on unpaid leave, a convenience store clerk is beaten, in Boston a man is executed- and it is miserable weather. Gray, foggy, rainy, depressing. Jesse is avoiding life and drinking harder.You will not be able to stop, because this seems like the final chapter of his life. Maybe it is the parade of old characters: Capt Healy, Rose, Suitcase, Reggie the dog- all of whom form an ensemble supporting the crotchety old detective. The robberies have Paradise PD frustrated and Boston homicide hire him to puzzle out their murders. At last, a purpose for him!'This is a small town', and you should come live here with us.

reviewText: This is Chapter Six in the series of Jesse Stone movies.  The same great cast continues the story line established in earlier chapters - answering questions left hanging in the previous movie and leaving some open ends for the next movie to tie up.  The understated acting, sombre cinematography and haunting Jeff Beal music continue to serve up the same quality that fans of this series has come to take for granted.  Count on this movie to deliver the same caliber entertainment you've come to expect - You won't be disappointed.
summary: Can't Wait For Jesse Stone Number 7

reviewText: Actually, I can't remember what channel these were originally airing on, I always missed them or saw small parts of the other movies, but a store recently had four of the these movies, except they didn't have "Stone Cold", nor the latest, this one of "No Remorse", so after already buying the prequel at a garage sale for a buck fifty just by chance last month, I got three more for buy 2 get one free, $9.99 movies of what I didn't have, so I am doing good in saving money on these.Oh, I have always liked Tom Selleck acting, and the movies are pretty much okay in my book, and I just rented "No Remorse" and plan on adding it to my collection later, though missing "Stone Cold", which I'll get soon, and this one when it goes down in price.Of course, there is the interesting "ending" which sort of leads into either next years film , one can only guess what will happen next movie, I mean, ha, there better be more.My only thing I knew was "off" on all these movies, is that there is no way in heck that a place like Paradise exists somewhere on the coast near Boston, probably nowhere in Massachussetts coastline, maybe in Maine maybe, would have been correct in a few places on the Oregon coast.  But who really cares, its just entertainment, made for t.v. entertainment, and good wholesome fun and mystery/intrigue.There is some excellent acting in this movie, I mean real pro's who know how to get the audience involved, or at least thinking instead of vegetating.
summary: Good enough and keep em coming, unanswered questions ending though
Title: N/A

reviewText: With the passing of author Robert B. Parker, the tone of the series of television "Jesse Stone" movies has become much darker, with star Tom Selleck, particularly in the last installment, "Thin Ice", appearing to be losing the battle with his personal demons...well, the latest film, "Jesse Stone: No Remorse" is still dark, but I actually found it more upbeat, despite a series of obstacles that would test Job's patience!On suspension from the Paradise Police Department (a carry-over from "Thin Ice"), Chief Jesse Stone (Selleck) is downing a fair amount of Scotch (to the disapproving gaze of his dog, Reggie...which Jesse insists isn't 'his' dog, even after sharing his home for 3 1/2 years!) His ex-wife is still trying to maintain a phone relationship, forcing him to rip his phone out of the wall (and break down and buy a cell phone). His Boston P.D. buddy, Commander Healy (Stephen McHattie) needs his help as a 'consultant', as a serial killer is on a spree; a convenience store killer in Paradise is overtaxing the community's tiny police force (Kathy Baker and Kohl Sudduth), with the City Council hoping the pair will fail in their investigation, so the entire department...including Chief Stone...can ALL be fired, and replaced! The ex-wife (Krista Allen) of the man who hired him, originally (Saul Rubinek), offers Stone her body, Officer Gammon (Baker) is facing a divorce, gangster Gino Fish (William Sadler) appears to have ties to the Boston murders, and long-suffering therapist Dr. Dix (William Devane) admits he hates fishing! A full plate for Jesse Stone, indeed...As with all the movies, a brilliant ensemble cast keeps things moving, and I cannot praise Tom Selleck, enough. His performance is restrained, yet intense (watch his body language and listen to his voice when he warns a young friend at a convenience store to be careful...simply brilliant acting!) There is more humor than in "Thin Ice", although it is dark and a bit sarcastic (understandable, given the circumstances). And the finale is positive (even if we don't get to see it all the way through...a new film, "Jesse Stone: Innocents Lost", has been filmed, so we can be pretty sure things will work out!)Another chapter of the Saga definitely worth owning!
summary: Another Dark but Rewarding Tom Selleck "Stone" TV Movie!

reviewText: There might be some minor spoilers in here.First off, I'm a huge Selleck fan, and I'm an even bigger Parker fan. I've read them all, and I've seen all the Stone, made for TV features.By shear coincidence my Netflix arrival on Saturday was Jesse Stone: ThinIce, which I missed last year, and by another bit of coincidence I wasable to drive back from along road trip in time to see No Remorse last night.Robert Parker got a tribute reference on the reel but I'm wondering if hewould have approved the direction Selleck and Harmon have taken with hischaracters. If I'm not mistaken Thin Ice and No Remorse were written fortelevision based on characters created by Parker, whose last Stone novelwas Stone Cold in 2004. (I have since learned from a friend that Parker got to see No Remorse before he passed away. According to this friend, Parker approved and enjoyed the effort.)Clearly, Selleck and Harmon have had a long and prosperous relationshipwith Parker, and I can envision a real sympatico there. So take mycriticisms with a grain of salt, or two fingers of Johnny Walker Red,iykwim.Over the course of this novelization, Parker gave Stone one seriouslypathetic Jones for his crazy, mixed-up, slut of an ex-wife. I can'tremember which ones they were but I do remember throwing a couple of booksacross the room and yelling: "For Chrissakes, Stone, GROW A PAIR!!!"However, the books didn't leave me with the overwhelming sense of dreadand despair imparted by the solemn, stoic, depressing expression Selleckwore for nearly four hours of my TV viewing Saturnday and Sunday. "For Crissakes, Selleck, can't you just once curl your upper lip a little!!!!?????? Or how aboutpet your freakin' dog?"All of Parker's hero characters seem share one thing in common, anundeniable and completely trustworthy moral compass, which makes them alldog lovers. If Selleck doesn't touch his dog in the next entry of thisseries I am going to sick PETA on him.Seriously, there are a few things Selleck has done with the Stone character withwhich I am in complete disagreement. But, that's OK. I'm in it for thelong haul. I'll keep watching. I like Selleck, and I love Parker's characters.Granted, I was probably tired, but No Remorse seemed a little disjointed. Itdidn't have Parker's signature simplicity. I mean, the crime aspect, thedetective work, was very simple, but there was so much background andpersonal stuff going on it took me away from the story. Normally, when Parker tells a story, he does it as follows: 1. Something bad happens. 2. Parker's character is on the case. 3. Character goes from place to place and shakes some trees. 3. Some unrelated stuff happens in between that helps define the character. 4. Fruit finally falls out of the trees and Parker's character makes a fruit salad.This one was like: 1. Something happens. 2. Stone is on the case. 3. Thenhe's fired. 4. Then all this stuff happens that makes the characterconfusing. (He's this. He's that. He doesn't know how he feels. He'swicked sad. He gets a cell phone).5. More stuff happens that doesn't haveanything to do with the story. (Suffice it to say that nobody stays married for very long in Paradise.) 6. Stone talks to two people about the case. 7. A Buick falls out of a tree, and Stone basically says: "So much for that."Lastly, the story leaves on a cliff hanger, well, not so much of a cliff hanger as maybe a ledge hanger. But we pretty much already know what's going to happen, because we know we're going to see Jesse again, and most probably in Paradise.~seabgb

reviewText: It's a movie. Isn't it nice to have something to actually look forward to on a Sunday night? Seriously. All the junk on tv these days...it's so nice to be able to anticipate a tv movie besides something from Hallmark. My family had the date marked on the calender for weeks just to be sure we didn't miss it.Jesse Stone IS a dark character, so it naturally follows that what goes on in the series will be dark. But his interaction with the rest of the cast of characters is so great, and we all can see his developing fondness for Reggie. How could one NOT love Reggie? He loves Reggie but is afraid to let himself show it. Same with his other friendships. CURSE YOU, JEN!While I really like Kathy Baker, I also miss Molly's character. It would be nice to have them both back in some way. After all, the Paradise PD needs staff, right?Suitcase is a treasure. I also love the psychiatrist(although I get the urge to break out an inhaler while watching his scenes) and Capt. Healy. Everyone in the show is great. A wonderful cast of character actors. Character actors are the spine of entertainment (ask me--I was a theatre major).This last episode seemed to bring in so many of the old characters from previous ones. It was great. No, it wasn't quite as good as some of the others, but still, it was great, compared to what we're offered on tv these days.So keep 'em coming, Tom and crew. Tom Selleck just gets better and better. He was an adorable younger man, and now he's a gorgeous and introspective mature man. It just doesn't get much better than that. Besides, who has ever had a better 'stache or brows? No One!

reviewText: We have truly enjoyed all the Jessie Stone series of films so far.  However, the first four were excellent; this one suffers from the lack of development in the main and secondary characters.  In the first few in the series we were getting to know the main character and some of the regular secondary ones. The series played well and the stories were well developed. However, there are only so many ways to present an alcoholic police officer without developing his personality more thoroughly. So it became a repeat of scenes with slightly different story lines -- an independent depressed police chief, who drinks Johnnie Walker Red nearly every night, is the hero protector of the weak and victimized with the help and support of a small group of folks who really love and appreciate him for his unseen finer qualities.  A drunk who encounters new attractive female characters in the process of carrrying out his duties who seem to universally want him as a lover.  Interesting connections the first few times, but the formula becomes old by this point. Also, "No Remorse" appears to add more of the action film flavor (scenes of shootings, blood spattering and flowing abundantly); whereas the first several were developing the characters and their relationships. Part of the issue of a series getting tired and repeating itself.
summary: Good But Not Like the First Four

reviewText: I was a fan of the character "Jesse Stone" long before the TV series.  Tom Selleck is perfect for the role.  All of the TV movies have multiple story lines, a mystery, a tug of the heart strings, a glimpse of Jesse that always reveals something about many of ourselves, how tough it is to communicate with those we love.  And, as the series goes on, Jesse grows as a person in his personal life and his detective skills are sharpened in surprising ways.  I am re-seeing the movies because it has been a while since I originally watched them.  It appears that they are not going to continue at one every year - very sad.  If you have a thinking brain, the choices for TV watching keep getting smaller and smaller.
summary: One of the best series available

reviewText: Negatives:(1.) The dialogue in every other sentence consisted of five monosyllabic words (give or take a word) e.g. our lead cop with this insightful statement "This isn't going very well". Not kidding - really weird to see & hear. What does that suggest?(2.) When the music creates the overbearing tone (especially when it's a single monotonous piano key) to the movie then it's obvious that the acting and story need some help.(3.) When you have the hee-haw stereotypes of a pair of bumbling country cops (one is always a female) being helped by a disgraced boozing cop with a dog chasing an attractive nun (who, by the way, saves prostitutes and has her hair permed and is named Sister Mary John). Add in the stereotypic bad guys involved in some semi-legal enterprise that includes a boxing gym. They also happen to sound & look like Hollywood actors.(4.) Finally, the ending scenes made no sense with two guys being arrested outside a convenience store with cops already waiting for them. That just seemed tossed-in to finish some loose ends in the story. Oh, and in the closing scene some other guy gets hit by some unknown car - no explanation and end of story.

reviewText: Just watched this DVD.  I love Jesse Stone movies, but the script of this one was very lame.  Every Jesse Stone characteristic and saying from all the other movies that had been established was brought up in this movie--and done so in a very obvious way. Sissy offers herself again to Jesse.  Hasty's tie lights up.  Jesse is drinking and everybody's concerned.  Jen calls, and Jesse and she have the exact same conversation you've seen in all the other movies, etc., etc. Jesse goes to his shrink and they talk about drinking....again. The conversations in the first part of the movie are very mechanical.  The last third of the movie flows much better.  If you are a Jesse Stone fan as I am (I own all the other movies) I would encourage you to rent this one, but not purchase it.  I'm not sure you can take this one twice!

reviewText: Every writer has his and her own writing style, and some stand out, and readers look forward to reading this style along with the tale itself. Robert B. Parker, who passed away in January 2010, was such a man. He wrote the Spenser novels as well as others with other outstanding lead characters, including the Jesse Stone series. This film is based on one of his Jesse Stone books, and it captures the spice of Parker's writing as much as films can do so. The language is Parker's and this makes it great. It lacks the humor that is always in Parker's speech and the sly references to literature, both of which are also Parker trademarks, but this loss, although large, does not detract from the film or from the acting in it.There are two series of crimes in this tale. Jesse has been suspended without pay from serving as Paradise's Police Chief. He is hired by the State Police to consult on solving several homicides. He left behind two deputies who the town council plans to fire. If the deputies can solve a series of robberies, they will stand a chance of not being fired.
summary: This is an excellent film with excellent dialogue

reviewText: As a result of his Thin Ice feud with the Paradise City Council, police chief Jesse Stone is suspended from his duties and his former colleagues on the force are forbidden to talk to him.  Jesse is pretty depressed and drinking a lot, but he does finally decide talking to his ex-wife Jen is a bad idea.Things start to look up when Healey of the state police invites Jesse to consult on an apparent serial killer case in Boston and there's been a rash of convenience store robberies in Paradise that Rose and Acting Police Chief Suitcase feel inadequate to cope with.  Since Jesse also spends a lot of time with his psychiatrist trying to figure out why he can't give his dog affection, his schedule fills up fast.  He also needs to learn how to use a cell phone since there was an, ah, unfortunate accident with his land line.  Because of the interdiction on Jesse's communication with Suitcase and Rose, the cell phone becomes a plot point and the cloak and dagger element just misses being comic.Jesse doggedly pursues the serial killer who seems to have a connection with the boxing promoter Gino Fish, and aids Rose and Suitcase, who need Jesse's help in identifying the perpetrator of the convenience store robberies from security tapes.  The entire Paradise police department in a superb display of teamwork catches the convenience store perp. The serial killer case is wrapped up in the last few minutes of the movie in an incredible twist that left me saying, `Huh?'With No Remorse, the movie character of Jesse Stone diverges irrevocably from that of the late lamented Robert Parker's books.  He's more angst-ridden and struggles in ways the book Jesse doesn't.  No Remorse, co-written by Tom Selleck, is dark. All the characters are having major problems both on and off the job to the point that it's almost painful to watch.  The delightful  repartee that's always been a feature of the Jesse Stone movies is much heavier handed and honestly, the movie could use some comic relief in addition to Jesse's problems with his cell phone.  Several plot threads were left dangling but I read there will be at least one more Jesse Stone movie, so perhaps things will be resolved.Three and a half stars rounded up to four.  I really missed the lightness of touch of the earlier entries. And I still miss Molly.

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of this series having watched the previous 5 Jesses Stone movies several times. I've always liked Selleck and think this is his best role ever. Having said all that, the 6th movie in the series is a huge let down from the previous 5 ,in my view. First without spoiling anything a character from one of the previous films returns in this one on parole after comitting a crime that should have kept them in prison for 10 years at least! Then, their's Tom Selleck spending most of the movie disheveled, depressed, bordering on 'whimpy' cause he's on administrative leave from his job as Chief of Paradise PD. In the first 5 films he's the perfect balance of tough, independent, caring, but flawed while here he's almost painful to watch having totally lost his 'mojo'. In addition the other two cops in Paradise played by Kathy Baker (the series really misses Viola Davis by the way) and Kohl Suddeth have lost the 'grit' they had in the previous films too.This installment isn't a total loss. The great William Sadler is back as gangster 'Gino Fish' and when Tom Selleck goes to him to investigate a crime/murder their interaction is the best part of the film. The case with Gino concludes with an ending that is shocking--but satifying. The other story thread about a crime closer to Paradise is just 'ok' and needed more work.And one final thing; I found the ending totally unsatifying apart from the fact that they obviously can't leave the series as it is so at least one more Jesse Stone would have to be coming I would imagine. Will I watch another film if they make one? Absolutely! This was a subpar effort but overall this series is one of my very favorite "cop shows, for grown-ups" as I like to call it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "No Remorse" is another reliable entry in the melancholy but engaging Jesse Stone series.  The underrated Tom Selleck is joined by many of the series regulars, and their usually quiet interactions are among the greatest pleasures of the film.  The plot builds slowly, as Jesse Stone plots do, but is punctuated by moments of violent action.  "No Remorse" isn't for everyone.  Some might find it too slow, others too melancholy, but for fans of the series, or of Tom Selleck, its a solid offering.

reviewText: I believe they did Robert Parker justice when they opted to have Tom Selleck portray Jesse Stone. He does an excellent job of it. He's moody, drowning in booze, non-talkative with one word answers. He's lonely as hell, craves human & animal affection, but will never admit to it.No Remorse does a nice job of fitting two story lines together. It melds them very well. The ending delving into the Paradise Police Department's staffs future. is a cliffhanger that fits well. Oh, Reggie is adorableSad to see "In Memory of Robert B. Parker" at the end though. He will be missed
summary: Good Actor, Good Story, Good Ending

reviewText: The setting for this series had a change of scene; the action moved to Boston.  There's a spate of murders there and with Jesse suspended from the Paradise Police Force, his friend, the state homicide detective wants Jesse's detectively intuition to help him with a case.So Jesse gets to snoop around Boston.  Some nefarious characters from previous episodes make cameo appearances in this episode: Gino Fine and Hasty Healy.  And unfortunately we get to hear Jen's grating voice once again on the telephone.When Jesse isn't in Boston, he's helping Suit and Rose investigate some local convenience store robberies.  I think he needs a new love interest to take up the slack.Last night I kindled one of the Jesse Stone mysteries as I wanted to compare Robert Parker's writing style with the tone and mood of this film.  Jesse is as cryptic in the book as he is in the movie.  You can pull the dialogue directly from the book and put it into a script if you wanted to.  It's a screenwriter's dream. So, the series seems true to character to the book.This was a very satisfying mystery with perhaps a few unbelievable aspects, but they provided a fine dramatic touch so I didn't mind.
summary: Do You Like a Change of Scenery?

reviewText: I love this series. I picked up the first one in a grocery store, expecting nothing, and got a great story (by robert parker) and great acting by tom selleck. I wanted to write him a thank you note about his great performance, something I never do, but could not find where to write........Supporting cast are uniformly fine and soon I had all the DVDs, a book or two.  All great stuff, some a bit better than the rest.....Then along comes "No Remorse," and I have none, but it is not as good as the others...Material repetitive, less humor, some characters drop in and out with no development, and, all in all, lacking the fine stuff that came before.If, like me, you loved the old stuff, you will need to see this one too, just in case they make another, but come expecting less, and maybe two glasses of scotch to get all the way done......Remember Jaws II and Caddyshack II, it's much better than those....

reviewText: I've read a number of the reviews of this movie.  Many of the reviewers stated that this one featured a darker Jesse Stone.  There's a good reason for that, which I will comment on later in this review.  I'm a big fan of the Jesse Stone movie series, and I particularly liked the first four in the series (Stone Cold, Death in Paradise, Night Passage, and Sea Change).In this latest installment, Jesse Stone (even while he is officially suspended by the Town Council of Paradise) helps his friend Healey (Captain of the Boston Homicide Department) and the Paradise Police Department to solve a series of mysterious killings in Paradise.  Capt. Healey hires Jesse as a consultant to get his "coply intuition" in an effort to find clues to solve the case;  meanwhile, the overworked and undermanned Paradise PD, represented by Rose and Suitcase, also seek Jesse's help "unofficially." These killings seem to be linked to the mob, but there are no definite clues.  Meanwhile, there is sub-plot with Jesse's struggles with how to operate his cell-phone -- everyone's trying to leave messages for him.I liked "No Remorse" because it offers a deeper inside look into Jesse Stone's struggles, personality, and relationships.  He has deeper interactions with people like Rose (the assistant to the Chief), Suitcase (now the Temp Chief), Healey (the Boston Homicide Chief), and his conversations with the crime boss Gino Fish and his assistant are more extensive.There were some comical moments in this film.  His conversations with Hastings (the former town council boss he put away in Night Passage) were amusing.  Hastings is now a used car salesman and he likes to tell Jesse "I'm very fond of you, Jesse", to which Jesse replies, "Whenever you tell me that, bad things happen!"  Jesse also has an amusing and awkward chat with a female nun over dinner.  Meanwhile, Jesse also tries to reach out and show affection to his dog as advised by his therapist.  These scenes helped to lighten up the mood.If Jesse Stone seems "darker" in "No Remorse",it is because he is depressed & devastated by the official suspension of being the Chief.  Jesse Stone loved his job and he was so gifted in solving difficult cases. He was born to be the Police Chief in Paradise and he did a brilliant job.  Tom Selleck and Michael Brandman did a masterful job of writing the original script to this entry;  they were sensitive to what was happening with Jesse Stone's character.  It would make sense that Jesse would not have the same light-hearted banter that characterized the first four series (because he's not the Chief anymore, and he's depressed).  The script gave us more of a personal look into Jesse Stone.  We also get a better glimpse of his relationships with people.  We see his affection for his former co-workers (Rose and Suitcase) in the Paradise Police Department, his care for the girl Emily who works at the convenience store, and his friendship with Healey, who helps him out by hiring him as his consultant.  We also hear a richer dialogue with Jesse's shrink; one of his sessions proves to be very significant in helping Jesse find the right clues in the case.I thought "No Remorse" was much more satisfying and suspenseful than the depressing and dismal "Thin Ice."  I enjoyed the rich character development, the deeper personal look at Jesse Stone, and the suspenseful story.  What is sadly missing in this DVD are any special features:  there are no interviews, no featurettes, and no commentary (hence the deletion of a star). Now, that's dark and depressing!!
summary: A very satisfying entry in the Jesse Stone series

reviewText: Given the negative comments from some reviewers,I was hesitant about buying this latest episode.Having enjoyed the previous films in the series,I decided to purchase 'No Remorse'.Yes it is darker in tone,but with Jesse suspended without pay,the PPD under threat,and his friend still recovering from his wounds,this comes as no surprise.The joy in this film is the dialogue,the greater insights into certain of the regular characters,the interaction between characters,and the overall quality of the acting by the cast,but particularly by Tom Selleck.Despite the moments of violence,'No Remorse' is full of subtly written,and acted scenes,and nuanced conversations.The 'cliffhanger' ending  is,to my mind,perfect,and leaves one wanting more of Jesse Stone,and his 'coply intuition'.
summary: A worthy addition to the series.

reviewText: This is not the best Jesse Stone film, it varies from Robert Parker's stories and was co-written by Selleck. He has been suspended from his job as Police Chief in Paradise, and has been called by his friend Healey in Boston to assist in finding a serial killer. This leads to all sorts of problems for friends and enemies in the Boston area.In the meantime, his colleagues back in Paradise must look for the person or persons responsible for the thievery at some gas stations. Rose played by Kathy Baker is just the best. She knows how to play detective, and even though, at times she has to call Stone for advice, she does her job. Luther, played by Kohl Sudduth finds his bearings and is turning into a competent policeman.  William Devane, who plays Stone's psychiatrist, is doing his best to attempt to limit the amount if alcohol Stone consumes, but at times he has no control, and he admits it. Saul, a used car salesman is newly released from prison and helps Stone with contacts.Again, much time is spent on looking at Stone's life and his misery. Even his dog is tired of Stone's drinking. Too much time is consumed with Stone's emotional issues, and not enough time on the serial killer. It seems Stone knows who it is, and is wont to find that person, case closed.Recommended But Not As Good As The Previous Stories.  prisrob 09-02-13

reviewText: Jesse Stone. It's raining and it's hard to see. It's how Jesse Stone movies begin. The music is somber.Jesse Stone, Sheriff of Paradise, job is to see and find out who has killed without regard, without remorse: cold as the night is dark. It's particularity hard to see through the rain at night and wanting to see, to understand becomes a motivating force in Jesse Stone's life. Now that Jesse Stone has been suspended from the force for telling it like it is his job is tougher. At home with Reggie his Golden retriever,a bottle of booze, Jesse Stone has been left for the moment frustrated. Both Reggie and Jesse Stone are grieving; Jesse Stone has an unfaithful wife and Reggie's owner has died. It is hard to feel good. Yet thankfully Jesse Stonehas his work, has his purpose; find the killer and protect the people he cares for. Jesse Stone is no sloucher; he has been working with a Psychoanalyst to help him not only figure his character out but also find a way into the mind of an obsessed killer. It all sounds familiar to Jesse Stone. As Jesse Stone begins to understand himself his drinks becomes curtailed, and he develops a caring bond with Reggie. Recognizing that solitude has its limits, and booze is a bad friend, Jesse Stone is no longer between a rock and a hard place. Jesse Stone has turned the corner.RIP Robert B. Parker

reviewText: This series, of which I enjoyed the first few episodes, is losing its focus. It has become more a story of an alcoholic who can't come to grips with his divorce, now 3+ years in the rear-view mirror, than with the business of crime and investigation, which is taking the lesser role. We don't need to see yet another shot of Tom sucking up Scotch and sulking. We get it already. Selleck and William Devane are, however, always outstanding and very watchable, but this show needs to pick up the pace and get back to the business of being a good detective series.

reviewText: Good things first: I found parts fun because it was "old home" week.  All - living - characters from previous episodes make an appearance.  Often, they sparked good memories. I did like Hathaway, now used car dealer; Rose, experiencing family problems; Healy, recovering from his wounds from the last movie, and the shrink Dix, still asking questions.  And I liked the laid back scenery of Paradise. But too often characters repeat boring lines, "It's out there, you just need....", or, like Cissy or the Nun, add nothing to the story.  Also, I am tired of Jen - as, to his credit, is Jesse. Regarding Jen, and the other old characters, this show has Jesse reaching out to people for the first time.  It's done with a bit of humor.  So, possibly the show should have been titled "Jesse Stone, Redemption".Bad things second: Jesse is getting old to excite so much the female attention.  And the two unrelated crime sprees Jesse must solve are handled badly.  The writers spent too little time on these plots.  That made me unhappy, because minor changes at little cost could have made the conclusions more satisfying. I do not understand how, near the end, Jesse got to the ongoing crime scene in Paradise. ("Coply intuition" in place of a dead zone cell phone?) Or, why he told Geno Fish about Jesse's Boston murder suspect, unless he wanted Geno to have him killed. Which, when it happened, was implied to surprise Jesse.  Regarding this second case, it would have been easy to have Rose, Suitcase, or Jesse himself, follow the suspect after that confrontation with Jesse, since Jesse must have known that doing so might provide conclusive proof of guilt.  We did not even need to see the tail. Just have a phone call to Jesse, after which he can tell Healy where to search for the evidence.  Adding all of a few thousand dollars to the total cost of producing the movie?Given how they brought everyone back, I thought, "This must be the final episode", but at the end the movie implied more to come. Now that everyone has Jesse's phone number and he is no longer talking to Jen, that may imply a better luck next time. Redemption is still an option.

reviewText: John Updike famously said, "Ted Williams is the classic ballplayer of the game on a hot August weekday, before a small crowd, when the only thing at stake is the tissue-thin difference between a thing done well and a thing done ill." That's how I feel about Jesse Stone, another Californian transplanted to New England. Ted Williams didn't pay much attention to fielding, but what he did pay attention to, he did very well. The "Jesse Stone" movies don't do everything well, but when it comes to producing character-driven, moody, exquisitely paced, hard-boiled entertainment, they do very well. Then came "No Remorse". It isn't terrible, but it's lost some of the appeal. Here's hoping Jesse gets his mojo back.
summary: Uh oh, Jesse's lost some mojo.
